comments.text:
+Odd Fred I think you may find this interesting reading.
http://www.volokh.com/posts/1122414938.shtml

Inherit the Wind was a good movie, but the real history of the Scopes trial 
is far more interesting.

In 1925 Tennessee passed the Butler Act. A law that all thought would only 
be symbolic. But the ACLU wanted teachers to have the sole right to set the 
curriculum, so they advertised for someone to challenge the law. It was 
meant to be a case about academic freedom.

The citizens of Dayton saw it as a good opportunity to bring money into the 
town, & they asked Scopes if he'd agree to be the defendant. It was all 
meant to be a friendly affair.

The ACLU would get their test case, lose, & be able to appeal to higher 
courts. The town of Dayton would get a boost to its economy. Scopes would 
face a fine in theory, but it was understood that he wouldn't actually have 
to pay it.

Nobody really cared about creationism v evolution. But Creationists had 
always been fighting against the teaching of Evolution. The decision in the 
Scopes trial was overturned on appeal, but only on a technicality. The 
Tennessee Supreme Court ruled that banning to teaching of the theory of 
evolution was not in breach of the Establishment Clause.

It wasn't until 1967 that the SC of the USA took a different view. 
Evolution began be taught again in Tennessee schools. But Creationists are 
nothing if not determined.

They may have lost the 2005 Dover Trial, but the US populace still has the 
highest percentage scientifically illiterate people in the developed world. 
Which is such a shame. Because the best US scientists are the equal of any 
on Earth.

America produces so many extraordinary people. From that truly wonderful 
person & genius that was Richard Feynman, to Ted Nugent.

My mum taught me that if I couldn't say anything good about a person, I 
should say nothing. I have nothing to say about Ted.

But to give you an idea about how I feel about him. I can find good things 
to say about Sarah Palin.
comments.author: David Keenan

comments.text:
I think most agree that this actually started around the time of the 
Protestant "movement". For a long period of time, it was forbidden for 
"normal folk" to even read the bible (and most were illiterate anyways). 
Regardless, religious folk took the word of the bible literally for a very 
long time. Certainly far longer than this person claims...of this movement 
only having begun about a 100 years ago or so. In fact, it is around the 
turn of the century (1900) that atheism peaked. Once could argue that the 
emergence of the United States as a world power slowed down the atheist 
movement and in fact strengthened the Christian right.
comments.author: James Pak

comments.text:
For what it's worth, I seem to recall speaking to a theology student on 
this matter. They said that the literal interpretation of the bible and the 
genesis-based creationism movement sprung up around the time of the scopes 
monkey trials.

Scopes was supposedly a very strongly libertarian teacher, who believed in 
evolution and eugenics and so emphatically taught the subject in classes. 
Allegedly, this was opposed by a strongly socialist Christian  (there's a 
phrase you don't hear these days), who was instrumental in creating the 
creationist movement and the literal interpretation of the bible to 
counteract this highly right-wing viewpoint.

I'm not sure if I'm remembering this correctly, and I can't find any 
sources, so take it for what it's worth. But it's certainly and interesting 
point to consider.
comments.author: Odd Fred

comments.text:
He's talking in terms of US political history. Whatever their personal 
beliefs, the Founders clearly agreed that when it came to governing all the 
people, the US should have a secular government. The Establishment Clause 
clarified that.

The Founders were products of the Age of European Enlightenment, not 
Biblical literalists. There are not Christian or theistic references in the 
Constitution, only deistic ones, But the Declaration of Independence & the 
Constitution are clearly primarily secular documents to establish secular 
governance.

Worldwide the majority of Christians are not biblical literalists & they do 
not seek to live in Christian theocracies. But in the US the voice of 
Christian fundamentalists is heard much louder today than it was in the 
past. To the point now where Dominionists like Cruz & Bachmann get elected 
to high office, & science illiterates like Baby Bush can become President. 
It's depressing.

court of law? Also if this wasn't a christian nation the leaders would have 
eliminated the christians long ago dimply because no one else would put up 
with that trash. This is a pure christian nation and christians are always 
trying to blame their own evil deeds on others because they are too ashamed 
to admit just how bad they are. I personally chose long ago to side with 
the devil simply so I could give christians a dose of their own medicine. 
Not so fun when the shoe is on the other foot, is it?
comments.author: Erica Miles

comments.text:
Wrong. Most of the founding fathers were deists (they believed in a creator 
deity who created the universe who never interacted with it at all, versus 
the personal miracle-producing god of the Bible). Also answer me this.
The Ten Commandments are often called the most important rules a Christian 
should follow. If the US is a Christian nation, then why is it that only 
two (TWO!) of the commandments (thou shalt not murder and thou shalt not 
steal) are enshrined in the nation's law books and none of the others? 
You'd think that a Christian nation would enshrine all of them, wouldn't 
you?
The problem with calling a nation Christian is that if it were true, it 
would inevitably lead to those who are not Christian being treated as 
non-equal with Christians. You'd also have the problem of trying to figure 
out which denomination of Christianity the country is supposed to be. 
Catholic? Lutheran? Calvinist? Mormon? Baptist? Orthodox?
comments.author: exodiathecoolone

comments.text:
+sabotore
Why? its simple, because its very similar to the Roman Empire. The US is 
not a country thats minding its own business. It is an imperial country and 
is responsible for the majority of civilian deaths in the world ever since 
WW2. They have destabilized regions constantly so that it could suit their

comments.author: Qas Wara

comments.text:
+Miranox I wouldn't say they were trying to maintain control over anyone 
during the cold war, but i guess that is a matter of opinion.
Also the US didn't start the cold war, the US was leaving all the other 
countries alone after world war two, it  didn't claim any territory after 
the war, while the Soviets were seeking to take over Europe and install 
their communism. However i agree the cold war could have been avoided 
peacefully. Also all countries can fit the definition of "empire" not just 
the US.

As for before the cold war, yes the US did invade north america to create 
their states, however that is how all countries are created, So yes i agree 
partially, All countries will collapse eventually, When? no one knows.

But by the looks of it the US isn't going to collapse soon, But its still 
possible I'll give you that, however I'd say there are  many less stable 
countries then the US.

As for the "get out of your bubble" thing, we all are in a giant bubble, 
ever heard of the atmosphere?

comments.text:
+sabotore
You need to learn some history, buddy. The US has been in war after war in 
which they try to maintain control over other countries. This is the 
definition of an empire. Most empires fall because of internal conflicts 
and corruption, not because someone else conquered them.

About 40 years ago, the US and Russia almost started a war that would have 
destroyed the entire planet. That possibility is still here. Russia, China, 
North Korea and Pakistan all have nuclear weapons. If they wanted to, they 
could destroy the planet at any time. Luckily they understand the 
consequences of nuclear war, so peace has endured. Get out of your bubble 
and learn about the world you live in.

comments.text:
+Tangerine Farmer Yes and no. Rome was already headed in a downward spiral 
even before Constantine's rule. The largest factor to Rome's decline was 
its inabilty to keep tabs on its immense land, leading to corruption and 
uprisings. What actually was one of the tieing factors of Rome was its 
religious freedom (except for Christians). However, when Christianity was 
made the official religion, only Christians in Rome were happy with the 
decision. Most other pagan religions were angry and soldiers meant to 
supress Christianity were out of a job. So more uprisings would occur (and 
Christianity would spread rather quickly). So did religion destroy rome? 
No. but it did speed it up
